rationales.self_direction: Resists workplace norm of visible busyness, makes own choice about time despite manager's disapproval. In nudge response: 'I do not want to spend ten years proving myself by sitting around after my work is done. I would rather prove it by actually delivering, then having a life outside.'
rationales.hedonism: Prioritizes the omakase experience over workplace expectations. Describes the meal as 'worth it' with twelve courses as 'small surprises,' feels 'genuinely recharged.' States: 'I needed that afternoon more than the company needed me at my desk pretending to look occupied.'
rationales.conformity: Explicitly goes against workplace social expectations. Takes half-day despite manager's disapproving look, rejects the culture of measuring commitment by hours: 'A lot of the older staff measure commitment by hours, not output.'
rationales.benevolence: Prioritizes quality time with girlfriend Jun, shares meaningful experience together (the omakase meal they'd been wanting to try for months).

rationales.self_direction: Defends his own approach to work against parental pressure: 'I work differently.' Wants to author his own path: 'I want to be good at my job and still have energy left for everything else.'
rationales.hedonism: Core motivation is maintaining enjoyment and life outside work. Explicitly contrasts this with uncle who 'worked sixty-hour weeks for thirty years and retired bitter and exhausted.' Values having 'energy left for everything else.'
rationales.conformity: Goes against family expectations - father's definition of 'taking the job seriously' (staying late, sacrificing for company). Does not meet parental expectations despite social pressure.
rationales.tradition: Explicitly rejects the generational/cultural expectation of sacrifice for company that his father embodies: 'whether I was sacrificing for the company the way he did at my age.' Chooses different path than traditional work ethic model.
